Lecture:  The Handtub Era: 1840-1862

Saturday, March 23, 2013

10:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m.

In the Millyard Museum

$10 general public, $5 for children 12-18, Free for children under 12 & for members of the Manchester Historic Association

Please RSVP for this event on the Manchester History Network Meetup website, or by calling (603) 622-7531.

This illustrated talk by Manchester firefighting historian Steve Pearson will explore the era of the hand-pumped fire engines which lasted from 1840-1862. Part of this talk will take place in the exhibit as Pearson shares the history of Torrent No.5, a handtub on permanent display in the Millyard Museum. Pearson is a firefighter with the Manchester Fire Department and author of the book, "Manchester Firefighting."

 

Read the full news release:

THE HANDTUB ERA IN FIRE FIGHTING HIGHLIGTED IN TALK AT MILLYARD MUSEUM ON MARCH 23

MANCHESTER, NH – Firefighting historian and author Steve Pearson will present an illustrated talk about the early fire engines of the pre-steam era at the Millyard Museum on Saturday, March 23. Pearson is a firefighter with the Manchester Fire Department and author of the book, Manchester Firefighting – A Pictorial History. His illustrated talk, The Handtub Era: 1840-1862, will start at 10:30 a.m. in the museum’s Discovery Gallery. Admission to the program and to the museum is $10 for adults, $5 for children 12-18, and free to children under 12 and members of the Manchester Historic Association. Reservations are requested by calling (603) 622-7531, or by e-mail: history@manchesterhistoric.org. 

During the presentation, Pearson will take the audience into the museum to get a close up look at Torrent No. 5, one of Manchester’s first fire engines, which is on permanent display. This hand-pumped engine was built in 1844 in Boston by the Hunneman & Company.  Torrent No. 5 was purchased by Manchester soon after the town lost its newly built brick Town Hall in a devastating fire in August 1844. During this era there was a great spirit of competitiveness among the many volunteer fire companies that served New England’s large cities and small towns alike. Torrent No. 5 was a successful contender in firemen’s musters in the region. In 1855 a Manchester fire company, with Torrent No. 5, won a muster in Worcester, Massachusetts by shooting a stream of water 150 feet in the air.

Steve Pearson is a fourth-generation firefighter. His great-great grandfather joined the Manchester Fire Department in 1895. Pearson earned an engineering degree in Fire Protection and Safety Engineering Technology, and a master’s degree in Fire and Emergency Management Administration from Oklahoma State University. Before joining the Manchester Fire Department in 2003, he worked for the Denton, Texas Fire Department and the National Fire Protection Association. Pearson is a member of the Manchester Historic Association, and a dedicated volunteer for the organization. He began his research on the Manchester Fire Department in 2008, and has pored over thousands of documents, newspaper articles and photographs to unlock the fascinating history of this great organization. For more information about Pearson’s work:  www.manchesterfirehistory.com.

 The Manchester Historic Association operates the Millyard Museum at 200 Bedford Street in Manchester, New Hampshire, at the corner of Commercial and Pleasant streets in the historic Amoskeag Millyard.  Museum hours are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. The organization’s Research Center is located at 129 Amherst Street in downtown Manchester, in the Victory Park Historic District. Research Center hours are Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and by appointment. Please call (603) 622-7531 for more information, or visit the website www.manchesterhistoric.org.
